name: Child–Parent Psychotherapy (CPP)
summary: An evidence-based, relationship-focused therapy for young children and their caregivers, designed to address the impact of trauma, attachment disruptions, and behavioral or emotional difficulties.
description: Child–Parent Psychotherapy (CPP) is a dyadic, attachment-based therapeutic intervention that focuses on strengthening the relationship between a young child (typically ages 0–6) and their caregiver. Developed by Alicia Lieberman and colleagues, CPP integrates attachment theory, developmental psychology, trauma theory, and cognitive–behavioral techniques. It is particularly indicated for families who have experienced trauma, domestic violence, loss, or attachment difficulties. Treatment involves joint caregiver–child sessions, with an emphasis on improving communication, repairing disruptions in attachment, and promoting emotional regulation. CPP has a strong evidence base demonstrating effectiveness in reducing child behavioral and emotional symptoms, improving attachment security, and supporting caregiver mental health.

conditions_treated: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) in young children
Effects of domestic violence or maltreatment
off_label_uses: Support for children in foster care or adoption transitions
contraindications: Situations where child safety cannot be ensured (e.g., ongoing abuse)
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and well-tolerated; emotionally challenging for families but supportive and reparative.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong—multiple randomized controlled trials and community effectiveness studies.
clinical_metadata.research_support: CPP is recognized as an evidence-based practice by SAMHSA and the National Child Traumatic Stress Network.

sections.text: CPP enhances the caregiver–child relationship by addressing trauma and attachment disruptions directly within the dyad. Sessions allow caregiver and child to process traumatic experiences together, with the therapist modeling supportive responses, fostering secure attachment, and guiding corrective emotional experiences. By improving the caregiver’s capacity for reflective functioning and emotional regulation, CPP indirectly supports the child’s behavioral and emotional development.

sections.preparation: Initial assessment of child and caregiver, including trauma history, developmental functioning, and relational patterns.
procedure: Weekly joint caregiver–child sessions with a trained CPP therapist.
Therapist facilitates shared play and narrative reconstruction of traumatic events.
Support caregiver in recognizing and regulating their own emotions.
Promote positive parenting strategies and responsive caregiving.

sections.pre_session: Therapist reviews previous progress and caregiver concerns.
sections.treatment_phase: Joint caregiver–child play and discussion; trauma processing when appropriate.
sections.post_session: Review of strategies, reflection, and planning for home carryover.

immediate: Increased caregiver awareness of child’s emotional needs

rare: Therapy dropout if caregiver cannot sustain engagement

relative: Families unwilling to engage in dyadic work

ideal_candidates: Children under age 6 with trauma exposure
Caregivers experiencing stress, depression, or parenting difficulties
screening_required: Evaluation of caregiver capacity and child safety

practitioner: Licensed mental health professional trained in CPP
Completion of CPP learning collaborative or approved training program

studies: Lieberman AF, Van Horn P, Ghosh Ippen C. (2005): RCT demonstrating reduced PTSD and behavior problems in preschoolers exposed to domestic violence.
Cicchetti D. et al. (2006): CPP improved attachment security in maltreated toddlers.
Ghosh Ippen C. et al. (2011): Community effectiveness study confirming outcomes across diverse families.
sections.limitations: Resource-intensive (requires 1 year of weekly therapy); therapist training is extensive; not always accessible in all regions.

sections.typical_session_cost: Comparable to family therapy ($100–$200/session in private practice, often subsidized in community programs)
sections.total_treatment_cost: Can exceed $5,000–$10,000 depending on length of care
sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered under family or child psychotherapy codes
sections.cost_effectiveness: Considered cost-effective given long-term prevention of mental health and relational problems

concurrent_therapies: Case management or social support services

sections.trauma-exposed-families: Particularly effective for children exposed to domestic violence, community violence, or abuse.
sections.foster-and-adoptive-families: Supports attachment building in new caregiving relationships.
sections.culturally-diverse-families: CPP has been adapted and validated in multiple cultural contexts.

items: CPP is one of the few dyadic therapies validated for very young children with trauma.
Focuses equally on child symptoms and caregiver functioning.
Effective both in clinical settings and home-based delivery.

seo.title: Child–Parent Psychotherapy (CPP)
seo.description: Child–Parent Psychotherapy (CPP) is an evidence-based, trauma-focused, attachment-based therapy for young children and their caregivers, designed to strengthen relationships and promote recovery from trauma.
